CHANGE.ITEM: *Proofed title page(s). *Reviewed structure. *Checked division-marking material at heads and feet of divisions (HEADS, CLOSER, OPENER, ARGUMENT, EPIGRAPH, SIGNED, BYLINE, etc.). *Added TYPEs to DIVs in order to validate. *Checked for N=""s. *Checked s. *Checked placement and completeness of PBs. *Checked for foreign, damage and missing-page GAPs, #, --. *Checked for LBs, startqs / endqs, q;s, {que}s, ABBRs and Qs. *Checked for FIGUREs and decorated initials. *Checked proofsheets and made corrections found there. *Corrected s and s etc. *Converted s to GAP DESC="illegible" RESP="[vendor name]". *Revalidated.

DIV1.P: THE SON-IN-LAW, A COMIC OPERA: AS IT IS ACTED AT THE THEATRES ROYAL IN LONDON AND DUBLIN.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I.
DIV2.P: FATHER! Sir! Do pray come out—I fear he'll do some mischief there.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Ah, ha! upon my word very well, very pretty indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Pretty! say elegant, my dear papa—Show me such another orchestra for a private concert—You have seen Drury-Lane, at an Oratorio.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Not I child.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: If you had, you must indisputably, nay, certainly would own that I have fitted out my little room, in a far superior stile—A stranger would imagine, nothing would produce such an effect, but the taste of a Cornely.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Ah! like enough child, like enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Ah! like enough child, like enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Ah! my dear papa, what inexpressible delight would it give me, if you had but a little taste for music.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Why I have Cecilia—I have a very great taste for music.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Yes, I have, for I stopp'd upwards of two mi∣nutes the other day, in Lincolns-Inn-fields, listening to the man playing on the little sticks.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Oh! Orpheus defend me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: I like a good song, or a good tune upon the fid∣dle—But at your confounded concerts, as you call them, they set up such a roaring, scraping and piping, that confound me if I can hear one for the noise of the other.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Ha! ha! but my dear papa—If I could prevail upon you to stay at home only this evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: I can't child, its Club Night.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: You'll be inspired with such a Gusto.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: A good song and a bottle that's my Gusto. I am an Englishman, Cecilia. I like an English song, and I'd rather hear the simple nervous strains of an honest Tar, in praise of a Rodney, a Hood, or a Howe, than all the squallini concerts in Italy. O! girl if you was but to hear a song at our Club.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Over a bottle.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Ay girl, over a bottle.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: They sing so charming, loud and strong.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Well, but I want to speak to you, upon a more serious subject—I am informed, you have an acquaint∣ance with Mr. Bouquet, a Hop Merchant.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Hop Merchant Sir! there's not a finer gentleman about Town than Mr. Bouquet.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Like enough, I never saw him, but my old friend Vinegar the Wine Merchant, tells me, there is not a greater coxcomb about town, than this Mr. Bou∣quet. His father was a Frenchman I'm told, he's a fop by inheritance.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: I wish Mr. Vinegar would mind his own affairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: So he does, so he does child—He has aquired a noble fortune by the importation of Port and Madeira.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Making Port and Madeira, you mean sir, he's an officious, impertinent, busy, meddling, old mischief-maker.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: He's my friend, child.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Sir, your child's enemy can never be your friend —Mr. Vinegar, talk of Mr. Bouquet—Mr. Vinegar is a mechanic, but Mr. Bouquet, is a gentleman and scorns to do any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Time enough for him to commence gentleman, when he has gathered the plum from the tree of industry —'Tis then a man enjoys the fruits of his labour.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Yes sir, and by the time this plum is ripe, he with∣out a tooth, will be obliged to mumble like old Vinegar.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: She loves him, I see that (aside.) Harkee Child, take my word for it, Bouquet will never be worth the kernel of a damason. I am told it is nothing with him but Ranelaughs, Pantheons and Operas.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Well, I like him the better.

SP.SPEAKER: Cram.
SP.P: To day, I am told, away rattling in his vis-a-vis, like a Venetion Ambassador.—Tomorrow, perch'd up in a high Phaeton, peeping into the people's garret windows—Now in his powdered gown, like a French Barber; and then you see him sliding down the Mall, in a pye bald coat—Buckles from the shew-glass, in Ex∣eter-change, and the face of a waiting maid, under the hat of a Russian trooper.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Believe me, sir, Mr. Vinegar's outre description is a most monstrous Caricatura. He judges of a gentle∣man, with his narrow ruffles, and twelve gray hairs tied up in a bassa bag.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: You love this Bouquet then.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: I do sir, I frankly own it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Well Child, I like your candour. You shall go with me into the country child, and I warrant there the beautiful revolutions of the seasons, will crase him from your heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Ah! dear papa, never, never.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Cecilia I tell you this, I love you as a parent ought, and therefore I never will approve of Mr. Bou∣quet's addresses, till he forsakes fashion and foppery, and returns to his hop-yards in kent, and his counting house in St Mary Aix.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Indeed papa, you are extremely cruel to me, my soul is never possessed of the lov'd idea of my sweet Bou∣quet, that you don't sour my temper with old Vinegar; and when I sondly imagine every obstacle to my hap∣piness removed, you throw a hop packet in my way, and cut off my darling hope, with an odious simmery aix.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: You know child, I mean it all for—

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Oh sir, you'll repent your unkindness to your poor Cecilia—Now for a seraphic strain, to soften, then leave him to felt at leisure.

DIV2.STAGE:
SONG.
CECILIA.
Tho' sweetly breathes the smiling spring,
Tho' gentle rains the flowers bring,
And hawthorn buds so gay, And hawthorn, &c.
In vain descend refreshing showers,
In vain peep forth the infant flowers,
My true love far away, My true love far away, &c
Tho' blooming spring to summer yields,
And promis'd daisies paint the fields,
And sun beams brightly play.
The sunny beams cou'd ne'er impart,
A ray of joy to this fond heart,
My true love far away, &c.
Shou'd plenteous harvest bless the plains,
And golden crops rejoice the swains,
And sweetly smelling hay,
Tho' all around is blyth and glad,
Cecilia's heart alone is sad,
My true love far away, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Poor Cecilia, yes she loves the Hop Merchant —'Twill break her heart if she don't get him—Poor child. Pshaw? what an old fool I am—I'll see this Bouquet—Perhaps he is not so bad as my friend Vinegar represents him—I'll send for him and if—well, I'll say no more till I see him—no, no, my child must not die of a broken heart neither—I'll send for him—Who's there—Oh Dolce get me, hold.

DIV2.P: Its here (goes to a table and writes.) Ay, ay, Mr. Bouquet Hop merchant, this I think fetches him—if Cecilia's love is returned—Dolce, call John hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolce.
SP.P: My Lady has sent him out, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P:
Ay he's running over the town hunting the
fiddles—well—oh apropos—Dolce, is not the young man below that brought me the letter just now?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolce.
SP.P: Yes sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: He'll do—send him up. [Exit Dolce. This young man is strongly recommended to me, by my old friend Docter Numscull the rector. He says he has a most surprising genius for oratory and elo∣quence, and all that—Oh here he comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Now shall I be stunn'd with a redundant flow of words, your servant sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: Up

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: I think sir your name is Mum.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: Mum.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: You brought me a letter from Docter Numscull of Somnus Hall.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: He writes me word, that you are a great ora∣tor, and very able disputant.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: Ay.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: And that your design in coming to London, is to deliver Lectures upon Elocution.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Have you fixed upon a place yet for your pur∣pose.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Well we must look out for some convenient large room for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: Ay,

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Are you married.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: You design it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: You can't fail of success amongst the Ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Your eloquence must have a powerful effect with them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: Ay.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: You have the art of persuasion.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Docter Numscull reports you a clever Auctio∣neer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: But I begin to have some doubts of your lo∣quacity.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: Oh, ho!

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Oh, ho! two syllables at once—I find you are a great orator.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: Ay.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: But your talents seem better adapted to the Parliament house than the rostrum—Should you like it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Have you much money.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Then if you were in Parliament, you'd soon, be a conscience out of pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: Aye.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: You'd not give your ayes for nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Will you carry a letter for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: Aye.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Here, its for Mr. Bouquet, Hop merchant, Buffolk street.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: Aye.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Come back here directly, and we'll think of your oratorial scheme.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: Oh ho!

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: You are the devil of an orator sure enough, his words are so precious, he keeps them all for the Rorum —Now for Cecilia—If this Bouquet is at all an eligible match, why in the name of goodness she shall have him, I were a malicious old ass, to debar my child from plea∣sure, I can no longer enjoy myself, I have had my day —though gad! when kisses were dividing, I did not come in for the smallest share—Ah! the little rogues— But I have done with them all.

DIV2.STAGE:
SONG.
CRANKY.
Maidens do not think me stupid,
If I view your charms unmov'd:
What has age to do with Cupid?
Age can ne'er again be lov'd.
When hairs are gray and blood is cold,
The heart shou'd not run wild;
For he who marries when he's old,
May kiss his neighbour's child.
Active in each am'rous duty,
I could ogle swear and lie,
To obtain the yielding beauty;
Kneel and flatter, sigh and die.
When hairs, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Bou.
SP.P: Idle, I think this will do.

SP.SPEAKER: Idle.
SP.P: If it could last, this is a glorious life of ours.

SP.SPEAKER: Bou.
SP.P: I bid fair for it, as I have for ever banished play from my fashionable amusements—blotted it out of my catalogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Idle.
SP.P: Right, sir, we are able to spend our money our∣selves.

SP.SPEAKER: Bou.
SP.P: Lilly, order my vis-a-vis.

SP.SPEAKER: Idle.
SP.P: Order our vis-a-vis! I don't like a vis-a-vis—I can't loll in it, I like to loll.

SP.SPEAKER: Bou.
SP.P: Idle, don't tell any body—keep it strictly from the people of the house, that I was a Hop-merchant, and you my clerk.

SP.SPEAKER: Idle.
SP.P: Tell—tis too much trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: Bou.
SP.P: Idle! Charming chemistry this of mine! What an aethereal spirit, to transmute earth to gold!

SP.SPEAKER: Idle.
SP.P: And gold to pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Bou.
SP.P: I have reserved a few Kentish acres though to sweeten matrimony.

SP.SPEAKER: Idle.
SP.P: Yes, but this disposing of one's property, is cursed troublesome—I wish you had done with it at once

SP.SPEAKER: Bou.
SP.P: I have sins enough in my list, not to add that of deceiving so amiable a girl as Cecilia.

SP.SPEAKER: Idle.
SP.P: Why, she would have you, without a guinea.

SP.SPEAKER: Bou.
SP.P: And for that reason, I wish I was worth a mil∣lion—I wish I could prevail on her to clope.

SP.SPEAKER: Idle.
SP.P: That eloping is so cursed troublesome—Elope! Why don't you step up to old Cranky, the father, and ask his consent?

SP.SPEAKER: Bou.
SP.P: Because I am certain of a refusal—Some imper∣tinent blockhead has been busy enough to tell him, what an elegant young fellow I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Idle.
SP.P: How the devil can people give themselves so much trouble!

SP.SPEAKER: Bou.
SP.P: Yes! The father, it seems, though he never saw me, thinks it a high misdemeanor, that I should quit the city, and prefer life to existence, without considering that I am at this time a combination of taste and splendour.

SP.SPEAKER: Idle.
SP.P: You look well enough; I should like to dress myself, but it's such a damn'd deal of trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: Bou.
SP.P: I flatter myself I am no bad match; but if she burns at priming, never more will I take aim by dress; never again cock my hat a-la-fuisse. I'll certainly dis∣charge my frizeur in a cloud of marischal, pair my nails, break my looking-glass, sell off my vis-a-vis, and return to St. Mary Alxein a Hackney Couch.

SP.SPEAKER: Idle.
SP.P: I would not take so much trouble for the finest woman in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Bou.
SP.P: I fancy, Idle, the demolition of the glass would be the last operation; for, absolutely, 'tis a most signifi∣cant interpreter of the glances of the face.

DIV2.STAGE:
SONG.
BOUQUET.
This face observe, discerning fair,
Observe each motion debonair;
My artois buckles when you view,
In shining sable sattin shoe,
You'll say, that I'm from top to toc,
A monstrous handsome city beau.
You'll say, &c.
My humble wisky I despise;
Like Phaeton I mount the skies;
And as I drive away like mad,
They all declare that I'm the lad,
And cry, he's sure from top to toe,
A monstrous handsome city beau.
And cry, &c.
Enter MUM. Knocks at the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: Oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Man
SP.P: Mr. Bouquet, Hop-merchant, in Suffolk-street —A Bouquet has had my apartments these three weeks; but this letter can't be for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: No, No!

SP.SPEAKER: Man
SP.P: No. He follows no busincss—he's a man of for∣tune and fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: Oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Man
SP.P: He's this instant gone out in his vis-a-vis—Hop∣merchant! —As sure as can be—Oh! I have it—ha! ha! ha! Hop-merchant—this letter must be for my neigh∣bour Bowkitt the dancing-master.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: Oh, oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Man
SP.P: Hop-merchant—let's see—Bou—ay, that's one way of spelling Bow—and Q-U-E-T instead of K-I-T-T, kitt; and because he's a dancing-master, they stile him Hop-merchant—Very comical, faith! ha! ha! ha! he lives at yonder door my lad, ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: Ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: No matter, say I am gone in the chariot, to give a lesson to the Countess of Cotillion—toll loll de roll.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: For me, ha! ha! (capers, and opens it) "Sir, in consequence of my daughter's partiality to your merit, I can no longer oppose Cecilia's inclination, that I should give her hand to you in the Temple of Hymen; for which purpose the bearer will conduct you to the house of your obedient servant, Thillegrew Cranky." So here's a new scholar, ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: Oh, ho!

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: And I am singled out for the honour of danc∣ing with her, in the Temple of Hymen—The Temple of Hymen is some new Ball Room, I suppose, for I never heard of it before! (looks at the direction) B-O-U-Q-U-E-T. Ay it must be a person of fashion, by not knowing how to spell my name—Hop-merchant! They have heard of my keeping the little dancing-school at Clerkenwell; that's unfortunate—You lead the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: We'll promenade as far as the Mews-gate; then hey for a Coach—Cast off.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: Hey.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Foot it, toll loll de roll.

SP.SPEAKER: Mum.
SP.P: Oh ho! toll loll de roll.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: John, is the young man returned?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: No, sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: I am quite impatient to see Cecilia's taste.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: A gentleman, who calls himself Bowkitt.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: This is he—Bouquet, you blockhead. Show him up—Bowkitt—An Englishman is so naturally An∣tigallican, that he cannot pronounce a word that sounds that way—Oh, here is my daughter's fancy! Your ser∣vant, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Sir, I have the superlative felicity to declare, with most profound respect, that I have the honour to profess myself, your most obedient, much devoted, humble servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: How he throws his legs about! (aside.) I presume, sir, you partly guess at the business on which I desired this favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Yes, sir, I understand you design to give a Ball!

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: A Ball!

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Yes, sir, in the Temple of Hymen.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: O yes, yes, sir! my daughter wishes to offer you her hand there.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: She does me a great deal of honour. The Temple of Hymen, of a new room is—

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: New! I think it is a pretty old room, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Hem! Very odd, I never heard of it before. I mean, sir, it is so spacious.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Why, I believe the Temple of Hymen is the largest room in the world—for scarce a night passes that some millions of couples are not leudown in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: A damn'd lying old fellow, this. (aside.) Yes, sir, the Temple of Hymen is much frequented by per∣sons of fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Yes, sir, and persons of fashion have lately adopted a mode of setting to cross partners; but I'll ven∣ture to say my Cecilia is, unfashionably, virtuous now, and I hope will ever remain so—though, sir, I find you are decreed her partner in this long dance.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Long dance—He's damn'd vulgar.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: As it's a dance that lasts you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: I do, sir, I am compleat master of all the dances now used in the politest assemblies of Great Bri∣tain, from the Scots reel to the Minuet de la cour.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Yes, sir. But as I am about to resign my child to your care, you'll not be offended if I frankly tell you, you had much better have stuck to your Hops, than meddle with reels and de la cours.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Oh, sir, thanks to taste and practice, I have done with hops long ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: More shame for you, sir. I assure you, attention to business, should be the strongest recommendation to my favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Sir, I challenge any gentleman of the pump in London, to pay a closer attention to business than I; for besides my private visits to particular ladies in town, I have no less than eight boarding schools—First, hey for Hackney—Chasee, for Hammersmith—Slide down for Chelsea—Cross over to Battersea—Figure into Stock∣well —Promenade to Newington—Borce to London Bridge—Cast down to Bow—So sir, you see I have pretty general intercouse with the ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: You are a great favourite, indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Oh! sir, ha! ha!

DIV2.STAGE:
SONG.
BOWKITT.
With an air debonair,
I instruct the ladies charming,
Sweet and pretty lovely fair,
And witty Susan, Jane, and Kitty,
I contrive to hit you.
Come away, all ye gay;
For the dance my trade is charming:
Sweet and pretty, lovely fair,
And witty, prithee come away.
See, see, see—The dancers are met,
What an elegant set!
While in country dance or cotillion
They dance, I regulate their paces.
Ye youths, would you the secret know,
When I advance, and make my bow,
Why I'm caress'd where'er I go:
I squeeze the hand, and point the toe,
And slide into their graces.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: But, sir, a word, if you are done with your qua∣vers and capers—If it is your passion—I say, sir, if you are so frolick some to dance after all the boarding-schools about town, my daughter can expect but little of your company.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Sir, I'll be with her three times a week.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: He'll make a devilish fashionable husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: One hour each visit, no more time can I spare, sir. No, no, must not neglect the boarding-schools—The sweet little angels.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: But, sir, if you are connected with my family, I presume you'll have no more to do with the little an∣gels.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Why, sir, I could not live without 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Here's a sellow going to marry my daughter, and tells me to my face, he can't do without three or four dozen of little angels (Aside)—and are you really of so amorous a constitution?

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: I amorous! Oh fie, sir, I mean all in the way of business.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Oh then, I fancy my daughter will sind em∣ployment for a cleverer fellow than ever stood upon your legs. But seriously, sir, have you entirely given up the Hop business.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Damn the Hop business, begging your pardon, sir, but I had rather not have it mentioned—it was a vile drudgery, exceeding low—no, no, Sir, the boarding∣schools for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: And another son-in-law for me. (aside) I wish you good success—Good morning to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: You'll send the young lady, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Indeed I will not—you won't do for my family.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Sir, I am extremely sorry.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Don't let me be so rash, though—Sir, one word. Are all your dealings with the Brewers at an end?

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: The Brewers, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Zounds! sir, in one word, have you any pro∣perty left?

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Property, sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Yes, property, sir—After all your reels and courants, could you scrape up a little capital, to begin the world again with?

SP.SPEAKER: Bow. [Takes out his kitt)
SP.P: Here, sir, is the little capital that I began the world with, and I'll scrape it up for you, with all my art and skill.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: He's mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: But my dear sir, why all this passion! I never had, nor can imagine that money is so necessary to our agreement, at least on my side—Do you find money, and I'll find steps.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Step out of my house this minute.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Sir, this is very strange behaviour.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Hop off, Mr Hop Factor.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Why zounds, girl! the fellow is not worth a snilling.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: What fellow!

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: But if you will have him, you must—You'll repent it, that's all—You'll find yourself neglected by him.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: I shall not neglect the lady, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Did not you tell me, you could not be with her but three hours in the week.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: I did so, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: There, there—but if you will have him, you must—three hours in a week with you only—And he's as amorous as the Great Mogul.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: N I sir, ot I, I am not amorous.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Oh! did not you tell me, you could not live without chasing after the boarding-school angels.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Sir, you may be as angry as you please, but I tell you again, I cannot neglect the boarding-schools.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: There, there—but if you will have him, you must. Oh child, child! he's a beggar.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Sir, I scorn your imputation—A beggar!

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Did not you say you had lost all dealings with the Brewers?

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Sir, I know nothing about the Brewers.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: There, there, but if you will have him you must, he's not worth a guinea, has not as much Hops as would produce a pennyworth of twopenny; he's poor, and to do him justice in my eyes, I never saw an uglier fellow—But as he's your choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Cee.
SP.P: My choice, sir—Who is the gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Who should he be, but your darling Bouquet, the Hop merchant of St Mary Axe?

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Not he, indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Who the devil is he then?

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Bowkitt, the Dancing Master of Suffolk-street.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: A Dancing Master!

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: At your service.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: And what brought you here?

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Pray, sir, is this your hand? (shews the letter.) You sent for me, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: I send for a Dancing Master! shew me. (looks at the letter) I, ha! ha! I have it, ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: What's all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: My dear, it proceeds from a confounded blun∣der of Orator Mum's. Ha! ha! ha! Instead of deliver∣ing my letter to your lover Bouquet, he goes and gives it to—What's your name, my lad?

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Lad! (Aside.) Bowkitt, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Give it to Bowkitt the Dancing Master, ha! ha! ha! but you will excuse what is past, my lad—You see what has occasioned it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: I knew there must be some mistake—But now, sir, I hope you will rectisy it, by sending for Mr. Bou∣quet. In the mean time I can only testify my concern at having been the innocent cause of any embarrassment to this gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Oh never mind it, Madam. I shall be happy to dance at your wedding.

DIV2.STAGE:
SONG.
Bowkitt.
You're so charming and fair,
Such a grace, such an air;
That you'll swim in the dance,
Like a lady from France,
And will prove, when a wife,
A good partner for life.
You'll swim in the dance, &c.
Cranky.
Some fathers would huff, frown and lour,
Insist on their absolute power,
And give up their childern for pelf;
But Cecilia, since you'll not agree,
To marry the man pleases me,
E'en marry who pleases yourself,
E'en marry who pleases yourself,
E'en marry who pleases yourself.
Cecilia.
Cupid! Hymen! Crown our love,
To a maiden's call attend,
To a maiden's call attend;
Faithful may the husband prove,
When the father proves a friend!
Faithful may the husband prove,
When the father proves a friend!
Cranky.
Cupid! Hymen! Hear our prayers,
Let the Graces dance the Hay,
Let the Graces dance the Hay.
Bacchus on thy ton appear,
This is Cranky's Holiday,
This is Cranky's Holiday,
This is Cranky's Holiday.
Feast and Holiday, and Holiday, and Holiday,
Feast and Holiday, and Holiday, and Holiday,
Feast and Holiday, and Holiday, and Holiday.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II.

SP.SPEAKER: VINEGAR.
SP.P: I Know he is at home.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: He is not at home, indeed sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: I am sure he is, though.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Why, upon my word sir, he is not.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: You lie, you lie, sirrah, he is above. Cranky— Old Cranky—Old Cranky I say—I warrant him here— Old Cranky I say—I say Old Cranky.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: Eh! he's not here, I find—But you impudent scoundrel, how dare you contradict me, when I said he was at home? Answer me that.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Because I knew he was abroad.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: You ought to know it was ill manners to con∣tradict. Eh! you Plebeian. Answer me that.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Sir, I—

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: Do you prate—I'll break your head, you scoun∣drel, I'll break your head.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Sir, sir—I—if you strike me—Perhaps—Per∣haps you'd find—I'll answer you that.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: You impudent, audacious—

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Gad's my life, what's all here to do—Hey friend Vinegar.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: Contradict me!

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Why, Vinegar, you are always wrangling with the servants—What have they done to you, that you thus declare open war against them?

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: War—no war—I'll use them as Rodney does the French, beat them wherever I meet them.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Yes, but shew a little less of the master, and you'll find your servant more of your friend. Go down John.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: Ay go down stairs, sirrah—Contradict me—Were, you abroad? Answer me that.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: I was, yes I was.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: You were not—but I won't contradict you, be∣cause it's not good manners—Well you were out— Where? Answer me that.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: I was in search of Mr. Bouquet, on whom I find my daughter has fixed her heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: In search of Bouquet—Not you indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Upon my word I was tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: No, but I won't contradict you, because it would be unmannerly.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: I think as you say, it would be unmannerly to contradict.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: Do you go to the Club to night? Answer me that.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: I intend so.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: No you don't; but I won't contradict you, be∣cause I know what manners are.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Yes, you're as polite as a Dutch Pirate.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: What!

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: I say we have a fine Summer before us.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: Cranky, you call'd me Pirate.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Not I—but I won't contradict you, because it would not be good manners.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: If you talk of manners, you may bid me sit down in your own house.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Well sit down then, and I'll give you a bottle of your own Port.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: I'd rather drink any body else's.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: John. (Enter John.) A bottle of Port,

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Yes, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: I'm a fine fellow, Answer me that.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: So you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: You have cause to say so—Retire. (Exit John.) Sing me a song, and I'll tell you a story.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: With all my heart.

DIV2.STAGE:
SONG
Cranky.
I like the plain song, without fine repetitions,
Soft cadences, graces, or running divisions.
I love Langolee, and sweet Gramachree Molly,
Or strike up the Jorum to chase melancholy.
Or strike &c.
With a bottle of Red give me bumper Squire Jones,
And the Tempest of War in bold Bannister's tones.
With old friends and old Wine,
Thus I feel no decay,
But a gentle decline,
As life passes away.
Good humour's our waiter, so drink and sit still,
For why should we part till Old Death bring the bill?
Why should, &c.
Why should, &c.
So drink and sit still,
Till Old Death brings the bill.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: There old Vinegar, that's my epitaph.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: I wish it was.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Thank you.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: Did you sing your best?

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Yes, I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: The worst song I ever heard.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Eh—but your story.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: Did you find Bouquet? Answer me that.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: You soon may.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Where?

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: In the Cage.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: What Cage?

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: In St George's Fields.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: The King's Bench.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: Yes, he's a man of pleasure, the Dog and Duck will be his Ranelagh, and he'll travel as far as the Lac∣tarium.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Faith.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: Think no more of him, I have a husband for your daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Who is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: Do you like a rich Son-in-Law? Answer me that.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: That's wonderful—Harkee—he's worth upwards of an hundred and twenty thousand pounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Is he handsome?

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: A little gummy or so.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Who is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: A great Italian banker; lately arrived from Ve∣nice, young, and very rich.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Well!

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: Come to London about a matter of business, but he likes it so well, that he talks of settling here, and taking a house in Portland Place.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Portland Place, well!

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: Has conceived a mighty passion for Cecilia, saw her at the Opera the other night: I met him at a friend's in Lombard street; he spoke in raptures of your daughter, and finding I knew you, gave me commis∣sion to break the matter to you—A fine affair! Answer me that.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: A Banker of Venice!

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: A great thing—Young and rich.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: A capital hit—If any man living can supplant this fop Bouquet—An Italian has the best chance—her passion for music makes her so exceeding partial to every thing of that Country.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: He's a prize, don't let him slip. I fancy he'll call on you this morning. I gave him your address. I told him you was a good natured stupid old fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: I am much obliged to you. You'll introducc him.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P:
No, I won't, I have business. He'll come with∣out ceremony, and he'll expect none. You know my way. I told him your character. Says I, my friend Cran∣ky is tolerably honest, as the world goes; but say that,
and you say all: I hear, says my Italian, Mr. Cranky spoke of as a very worthy old gentleman. The world's damnably given to lying, says I, for the only good thing I know of him is, that he drinks my wine, and pays me ready money, ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: You are very kind.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: No, no, he expects no good manners from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Not if he judges from my company. (aside) What's his name?

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: Signor—Signor—Curse these Italian names. I know it ends with an ini or an elli, or something that way.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: His coming this evening will be quite apropos, for Cecilia is to have a concert here, in the next room, and her skill in music must render her doubly amiable to an Italian gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: That's impossible that any can. He certainly will marry her, and I'd advise you to conclude the af∣fair immediately, for fear of accidents.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: My dear friend, I don't know how to thank you.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: I know you don't, you're so damn'd unmanner∣ly. Farewell. He drinks my wine, and pays me rea∣dy money, Signor, ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: That was extremely facetious, ha, ha, ha! You laughed very heartily at me.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: Yes, ha, ha, ha! and the Senior laugh'd at you in broken English. Well, good bye.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: You think he'll come this evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: Yes, yes, certainly. Farewel. Where are you going? Answer me that.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Only to ring for a servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: To watch, for fear I should slip any thing off the sideboard, in the parlour, as I go out. Is that your po∣liteness? Oh Cranky, Cranky, I fear I never can teach you good manners.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P:
That you never can indeed. There's a man, first waiter at a tavern in Fleet-street, marries his mas∣ter's widow, a Vintner ten years, commences Wine
Merchant, and in fifteen years amassed a fortune of fifty thousand pounds—Well done, old Vinegar—A lucky circumstance, though—If Cecilia accept of this Banker for a husband—Oh, here she comes, with a whole cargo of fiddles, drums, hautboys, sifes, horns and trumpets. Oh Lord! oh Lord! I must get out of her way, while I have the use of my cars.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolce.
SP.P: Oh, Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolce.
SP.P: Ah! Madam, I fear you'll see Mr. Bouquet no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: You surprise me. Why, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolce.
SP.P: You must know, Madam, old Vinegar has had a long conference with your papa; and happening, by accident to pass by the door, and hearing your name drop, I was tempted to listen—

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Listen!

SP.SPEAKER: Dolce.
SP.P: I'd scorn to listen for myself, Madam, but hear∣ing your name drop, and knowing Mr. Vinegar's dislike to your marrying Mr. Bouquet, I could not resist it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: What could you gather?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolce.
SP.P: As sure as I live, Madam, Mr. Vinegar has re∣commended a great Hessian, as a husband for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: A Hessian!

SP.SPEAKER: Dolce.
SP.P: Yes, Madam, a Banker it seems; and you are to be married to him immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Dear girl, I thank you for this information. This shock has so suddenly affected me, I shan't be able to recover my brilliante this five minutes; but tell the com∣pany, I'll do myself the honour of waiting on them presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolce.
SP.P: Yes, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: What a dreadful resolution—Such a sudden tran∣sition too—My Father, that not two hours since seem'd so anxious for my union with my sweet Bouquet!

SP.SPEAKER: Dolce.
SP.P: Don't be angry with me, dear Madam, for promoting this pleasing interview.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Mr. Bouquet!

SP.SPEAKER: Bou.
SP.P: My dear Cecilia!

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Ah! Mr. Bouquet, what a—

SP.SPEAKER: Bou.
SP.P: I have heard it all from Dolce.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: We shall never be united by my father's con∣sent, and without it, my heart is breaking.

SP.SPEAKER: Bou.
SP.P: Come my love, dry up your tears, we shall emerge from this envious cloud, and enjoy a full fru∣ition of love and happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: But how did you gain admittance?

SP.SPEAKER: Bou.
SP.P: As one of your band; but hearing Mr. Vine∣gar's voice, as I am certain he knows my person, though your father does not, for fear of discovery, I popt into the case of the double bass that lies in the Concert—room.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran. (without)
SP.P: John.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: My father's voice!

SP.SPEAKER: Dolce.
SP.P: Mr. Bouquet, Madam, had best retire to the old station till I am certain Mr. Vinegar's gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Bou.
SP.P: And must we part?

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: But for a moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolce.
SP.P: I Fancy Mr. Vinegar is still below stairs, but I must be upon the watch.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Dolce, my mind is now somewhat more at ease; my Father's caprice may soon take another turn, and that may be in our favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolce.
SP.P: Heaven send it, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: I expect Signor Arionelli here at the Concert. I have a notion of becoming his pupil; when he comes, shew him into the Concett—room.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolce.
SP.P: Yes, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: You know him, the Italian Opera singer, speaks in a small tone like a woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolce.
SP.P: Oh! I know him very well, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Now to assume all the cheerfulness in my power.

DIV2.STAGE:
SONG.
CECILIA.
Goddess of the magic cestus,
Queen of am rous arts and wiles,
How can we, when cares molest us,
Veil our agonies in smiles?
Goddess of the magic cestus, &c.
Whilst in dread surprise we tremble,
Whilst black cares and fears among,
Vain the errort to dissemble;
Vain to wear the face of joy.
Whilst in dread, &c.
In gratitude to thy exalted frendship,
I'll quit this scene of horror and despair,
But oh! thus exil'd, I shall only fly,
Restless, to tread the paths of misery.
[Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: John, if a foreign Gentleman comes, an Itali∣an d'ye mind, introduce him. () Run, run, per∣haps this is he—Ay, he'll make something like a Son∣in-law, and if I lind him as eager as Vinegar reports, I'll have the wedding solemnized this night.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Signor—I forget—the Italian gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: Umblissimo servo, Signor, is this Mr Cranky's house?

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: You are very right, Sir, my name is Cranky.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: Devotissimo servo suo.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: He has a mighty comical voice.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: The young lady your daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: How impatient he is to see her!

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: I have sir, a great respect for her taste in mu∣sic.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Sir, you do her a great deal of honour. Music, sir, is her great passion, and I have always encouraged her in the pursuit, particularly Italian music. I am tran∣sported with Italian music—I'd rather hear a Scots Bag∣pipe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: Sir, you are very obliging.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: He has a very droll voice.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: Sir, I am quite lanquente for the lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: How deeply he is in love with my daughter!

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: To convince her.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Oh sir, time enough for that, you shall have a full opportunity to cultivate a permanent esteem.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: I shall be careful sir, delegents in my part, to merit her favour,

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: I'll answer for my daughter—And for my part, sir, there is no man in England I am more anxious to have introduced into my family, from the excellence of your character; and therefore sir, if you please, we'll have every thing settled immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: Sir. I'll answer that after I sing one song.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: A song, sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: You can form a better judgment of my voice.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Oh, sir, your voice is a very immaterial point. A gentleman's character, sir, is—

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: Yes, sir, but I would convince you that my voice comes up to my character.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P:
I suppose he has a voice in the Senate of Venice,
that he makes such a work about it! (aside.) Pray sir, pardon me, are you a Senator?

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Perhaps you are a Venetian Parliament-man.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: Sir, I don't understand—

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Then I must come to the point, sir. We will adjust this affair immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: But sir, after the Concert—In the mean time, I'll sing you one little song.

DIV2.STAGE:
SONG.
ARIONELLI.
Water parted from the sea,
May increase the river's tide,
To the bubbling fount may flee,
Or thro' fertile vallies glide.
Tho' in search of soft repose,
Thro' the land 'tis free to roam,
Still it murmurs as it flows,
Panting for its native home.
Tho' in search of soft, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: What has a concert to do with the business in question? In a short interview with my daughter, you'll be acquainted with her qualifications. We'll send for our lawyers, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: Lawyers! dear sir, you are too particular, there is no occasion for lawyers in—

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Pardon me, sir, all these little formalites pro∣perly adjusted before marriage lays the foundation of future happiness; besides, a provision for the children, you know, is essential.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: Children, marriage—I beg your pardon, sir, I did not consider about—this marriage—but it seems your daughter is going to be married.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Certainly, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: I beg your pardon sir, I'll take my leave for the present,

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Take your leave!

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: Oh sir, I am not at all impatient.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Very odd this! (aside) You are not impatient.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: No, no, sir, any other time will do for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Sir you are grown very cool of a sudden—In one word will you be married?

SP.SPEAKER: Ari
SP.P: Sir, I don't understand.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Will you marry my daughter, that's the Eng∣lish of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: Sir I came here for a Concert.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Well my daughter is a Concert for a prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: Sir, I mean I came here to a Concert.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Oh! we'll stay for the Concert; but do you like my daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: She is very beautiful.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: And have you any thing to say against her vir∣tue?

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: O caro, no, Signor.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Then, zounds!

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: Sir, sir, your daughter is a very fine lady, and a very good lady—but for—marriage—it is quite out of my way.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: How are your affections engaged since you saw Old Vinegar?

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: I have no Old Vinegar, nor affections for any thing but my notes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Well, every banker should take care of his notes, but he might like a pretty girl too.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: Sir, I respect and honor the pretty girls; but for marriage—it will do for me to sing to the ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Sir, if you object to marry my daughter, you came to my house with a dishonourable intent.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: Sir, I!

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Sir, you disclosed your passion for my daughter to Old Vinegar—I believe Old Vinegar.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: I don't understand—Old Vinegar!

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Zounds, sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Oh my sweet Signor, we have been all lan∣quente for your presence.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Sweet Signor, oh! oh! now I see what ob∣structed the marriage. Oh thou wicked girl!

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: O thou vile seducer!

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: Signor!

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: What's the matter new, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: After all he won't marry you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: What all, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Has he not undone you?

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: Signor, I can undo no body.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Undone me, sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Yes, you profligate.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: What do you laugh at? Oh she is hardened in her iniquity.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Why, my dear sir, do you know who this is?

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Oh yes, madam, I know your Venetian Banker.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Why, sir, this is Signor Arionelli the Opera singer.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Nelly the Opera singer marry my daughter! Oh, I have mistook my man!

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: Madam, if you please, madam, I will go into the Concert.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Ay, ay, go, go to the Concert.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: La Rin—Grazio Signor shiavo suo Signor.

DIV2.STAGE:
SONG.
ARIONELLI.
Signor Cranky then adio,
Banish all your vain alarms;
Signor Cranky then adio.
Ah farewell, bell Idol mio,
To a Briton give your charms,
Ah farewell, bell Idol mio.
Signor Cranky, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: I am vested with myself, I have made myself so ridiculous with the opera singere and dancing masters. I believe something, I don't know what, interferes in this affair. Cecilia, I will be obeyed—and therefore I in∣sist that you take—

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Oh dear sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: The man of your choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Dear kind papa.

SP.SPEAKER: Cran.
SP.P: Come, exhibit your Concert—room—John.

DIV2.STAGE:
FINALE.
Cran.
No longer Cupid's foe, child;
To make you reparation,
For all your sad vexation,
Go please your inclination,
And take your lovely beau, child,
And take your lovely beau, child.
Cec.
Papa, I humbly thank you.
Cran.
Tune up your violincello.
This night I'll sure get mellow;
And as a kind old fellow,
Each lover here will thank you,
Each lover here will thank you.
No more I'll be absurd:
If Old Nick cou'd hither carry him,
You this very night shou'd marry him.
Bou.
I take you at your word,
I take you at your word.
Cran.
Hark! hark! for without doubt,
The voice comes from the bass.
Bou.
Make haste and let me out:
Cec.
My lover's in the case:
Cran.
A lover in the case!
Is this your beau, my dear?
Bon.
Yes, sir, and your obedient.
Cran.
And thus you got in here.
Cec.
A lover's last expedient,
A lover's last expedient.
Bou.
A lover's last expedient,
A lover's last expedient.
Cran.
I keep my word, her hand here take,
No more you'll play the naughty rake.
Bou.
For love, for love, I folly here forsake,
For love, for love, I folly here forsake;
I folly here forsake.
Cec.
Hail oh, hail, hail ho,
Hail, hail, oh matrimony divine,
Parent of the tuneful nine,
Parent of the tuneful nine,
Warbling, sporting, chirping, courting,
Warbling, sporting, chirping, courting,
Love and matrimony be mine.

CHORUS.
All.
Hail oh, hail, hail oh.
